article:
Silvio Berlusconi is an Italian media tycoon, businessman, and politician who served as the Prime Minister of Italy in four governments. He is known for his charismatic leadership style, flamboyant personality, and numerous controversies surrounding his business and personal life.

# Family background and personal life

Silvio Berlusconi was born on September 29, 1936, in Milan, Italy, to Luigi Berlusconi and Rosa Bossi. He was the first of three children, and his family was of lower-middle-class background. Berlusconi's father was a bank employee, and the family moved frequently during his childhood due to his father's job transfers. Berlusconi developed an interest in music at an early age and played the accordion in a cruise ship band during his summer vacations.

Berlusconi studied law at the University of Milan and graduated in 1961. During his university years, he became involved in the Italian Socialist Party and was friends with future Italian Prime Minister Bettino Craxi. After graduating, Berlusconi worked as a door-to-door salesman and later as a real estate agent.

# Business career

## Milano Due

In 1968, Berlusconi founded the construction company Edilnord Sas, which later became one of the largest real estate companies in Italy. He also founded the residential complex Milano Due, which was one of the first gated communities in Italy. Milano Due was a massive success, and Berlusconi's company sold over 4,000 apartments in the complex.

## TeleMilano

In 1973, Berlusconi founded the television station TeleMilano, which later became one of the largest private television networks in Italy. TeleMilano was known for its entertainment programs, and Berlusconi used the station to promote his own business interests and build his public image.

## Fininvest

In 1978, Berlusconi founded Fininvest, a holding company that controlled his various business interests, including his television stations, construction companies, and publishing houses. Fininvest became one of the largest conglomerates in Italy, and Berlusconi used the company to expand his business empire and increase his wealth.

# Political career

## Beginnings

Berlusconi's entry into politics was sudden and unexpected. In 1993, the Italian government was rocked by a series of corruption scandals, and the country was facing a severe economic crisis. Berlusconi, who was then a successful businessman, decided to enter politics and formed the party Forza Italia (Go Italy) in 1993.

## 1994 electoral victory

Berlusconi's party won a surprise victory in the 1994 general election, and he became the Prime Minister of Italy. Berlusconi's government was a coalition of his party, the Northern League, and the National Alliance. During his first term as Prime Minister, Berlusconi implemented several economic reforms and privatized several state-owned companies.

## Fall of the Berlusconi I Cabinet

Berlusconi's first government fell in 1995 after the Northern League withdrew its support. Berlusconi was succeeded by Lamberto Dini, a former Governor of the Bank of Italy.

## 2001 electoral victory

Berlusconi's party won the 2001 general election, and he became Prime Minister for the second time. During his second term, Berlusconi implemented several policies aimed at reducing taxes and promoting economic growth.

## Berlusconi II Cabinet

Berlusconi's second government was a coalition of his party, the National Alliance, and the Union of Christian and Centre Democrats. During his second term, Berlusconi was criticized for his close relationship with Russian President Vladimir Putin and his support for the US-led invasion of Iraq.

## Subsequent elections

Berlusconi's party lost the 2006 general election, and he was succeeded by Romano Prodi. Berlusconi's party won the 2008 general election, and he became Prime Minister for the third time.

## Berlusconi III Cabinet

Berlusconi's third government was a coalition of his party, the National Alliance, and the Lega Nord. During his third term, Berlusconi implemented several policies aimed at reducing taxes and promoting economic growth.

## Attempt to reform the Italian constitution

In 2010, Berlusconi's government proposed several constitutional reforms aimed at reducing the power of the judiciary and increasing the power of the executive. The reforms were rejected by the Italian Senate.

## 2006 general election and opposition

Berlusconi's party lost the 2006 general election, and he became the leader of the opposition. During his time in opposition, Berlusconi was critical of the government's economic policies and its handling of the European sovereign-debt crisis.

## 2008 electoral victory

Berlusconi's party won the 2008 general election, and he became Prime Minister for the fourth time. During his fourth term, Berlusconi implemented several policies aimed at reducing taxes and promoting economic growth.

## The People of Freedom split

In 2013, Berlusconi's party split, and several of its members formed a new party called New Centre-Right. Berlusconi's party was renamed Forza Italia.

## Resignation

Berlusconi resigned as Prime Minister in 2011 after his government lost a vote of confidence in the Italian Senate. He was succeeded by Mario Monti, a former European Commissioner.

## 2013 general election

Berlusconi's party lost the 2013 general election, and he became the leader of the opposition for the second time.

## Refoundation of Forza Italia and public office ban

In 2013, Berlusconi's party was refounded, and he became its leader. In 2013, Berlusconi was banned from holding public office for two years after being convicted of tax fraud.

## Political comeback and election to European Parliament and Senate

Berlusconi made a political comeback in 2019 when he was elected to the European Parliament. In 2022, he was elected to the Italian Senate.

# Foreign policy

## Relations with Russia

Berlusconi has been a strong supporter of Russian President Vladimir Putin and has maintained close relations with Russia. During his time as Prime Minister, Berlusconi supported the construction of the South Stream pipeline, which was a major Russian energy project.

## Relations with Israel

Berlusconi has been a strong supporter of Israel and has maintained close relations with the Israeli government. During his time as Prime Minister, Berlusconi supported the Israeli government's policies towards the Palestinians.

## Relations with Belarus

Berlusconi has been a strong supporter of the Belarusian government and has maintained close relations with President Alexander Lukashenko.

## Cooperation with the Western Balkans

Berlusconi has supported the integration of the Western Balkans into the European Union and has maintained close relations with the governments of the region.

## Relations with Libya

Berlusconi has maintained close relations with the Libyan government and has supported the country's transition to democracy.

# Berlusconism

## Political positions

Berlusconism is a term used to describe Berlusconi's political ideology, which is a mix of conservatism, liberalism, and populism. Berlusconi has been a strong supporter of free-market economics and has implemented several policies aimed at reducing taxes and promoting economic growth.

## Comparisons to other leaders

Berlusconi has been compared to other populist leaders, such as Donald Trump and Vladimir Putin. Like Trump and Putin, Berlusconi has been known for his charismatic leadership style and his ability to connect with ordinary people.

# Legal problems

Berlusconi has faced several legal problems during his career, including corruption charges, tax evasion charges, and charges of links to the Mafia. In 2013, Berlusconi was convicted of tax fraud and was banned from holding public office for two years.

# Controversies

## Economic conflicts of interest

Berlusconi has faced several controversies surrounding his economic interests and his conflict of interest as Prime Minister. During his time as Prime Minister, Berlusconi controlled several companies, including his television stations and his construction companies.

## Media control and conflict of interest

Berlusconi has faced several controversies surrounding his control of the media and his conflict of interest as Prime Minister. During his time as Prime Minister, Berlusconi controlled several television stations and newspapers.

## The Economist

In 2001, The Economist magazine published a article critical of Berlusconi's conflict of interest and his control of the media. The article was titled "Why Silvio Berlusconi is unfit to lead Italy".

## Legislative changes

Berlusconi has implemented several legislative changes aimed at reducing his own conflict of interest. In 2004, Berlusconi implemented a law that allowed him to appoint the head of the state-owned television company RAI.

## Accusations of links to the Mafia

Berlusconi has faced several accusations of links to the Mafia. In 2009, a former Mafia boss testified that Berlusconi had met with Mafia leaders in the 1970s.

## Remarks on Western civilisation and Islam

Berlusconi has faced several controversies surrounding his remarks on Western civilisation and Islam. In 2001, Berlusconi said that Western civilisation was superior to Islamic civilisation.

## Right-to-die case

Berlusconi has faced several controversies surrounding his government's handling of the right-to-die case of Eluana Englaro. In 2009, the Italian government passed a law that prevented Englaro's family from removing her feeding tube.

## Anti-immigration laws

Berlusconi has implemented several anti-immigration laws aimed at reducing immigration to Italy. In 2009, the Italian government passed a law that made it easier to deport immigrants.

## Jokes, gestures, and blunders

Berlusconi has been known for his jokes, gestures, and blunders. In 2009, Berlusconi was criticised for making a joke about the Chinese during a visit to China.

## Friendship with Bettino Craxi

Berlusconi has been friends with former Italian Prime Minister Bettino Craxi. Craxi was a key figure in the Tangentopoli corruption scandal and fled to Tunisia to avoid prosecution.

## Freedom Army

Berlusconi has supported the Freedom Army, a group of Italian citizens who have protested against the government's economic policies.

## Wiretaps and accusations of corruption

Berlusconi has faced several accusations of corruption and has been the subject of several wiretaps. In 2010, a wiretap was released that appeared to show Berlusconi discussing a corrupt deal with a businessman.

## Divorce and allegations of sexual misconduct

Berlusconi has faced several allegations of sexual misconduct and has been divorced twice. In 2010, Berlusconi's second wife Veronica Lario divorced him and accused him of having an affair with a young woman.

### Shots of Porto Rotondo

In 2011, Berlusconi was photographed with a group of young women at his villa in Porto Rotondo. The photographs appeared to show Berlusconi and the women in compromising positions.

## Rubygate

Berlusconi has faced several allegations of paying for sex with underage girls. In 2011, a Moroccan girl named Karima El Mahroug, also known as Ruby, claimed that Berlusconi had paid her for sex.

## Panama Papers

Berlusconi has been mentioned in the Panama Papers, a leak of documents that appear to show widespread tax evasion and money laundering among the global elite.

# Health

Berlusconi has faced several health problems during his career, including heart problems and cancer. In 2006, Berlusconi was hospitalised for several days after collapsing during a speech.

# Death

Berlusconi is still alive and active in politics.

# Personal fortune

Berlusconi's personal fortune is estimated to be over $6 billion. He has made his fortune through his business interests, including his television stations and construction companies.

# Electoral history

## First-past-the-post elections

Berlusconi has won several first-past-the-post elections, including the 1994 general election and the 2001 general election.

# Works by Silvio Berlusconi

Berlusconi has written several books, including his autobiography "The True Story of Silvio Berlusconi".

# Honours and awards

## Namesakes

Berlusconi has been the subject of several namesakes, including a species of frog and a type of pasta.

# In films

## Documentaries

Berlusconi has been the subject of several documentaries, including "The Berlusconi Case" and "Berlusconi: The Untold Story".

## Feature films

Berlusconi has been portrayed in several feature films, including "Loro" and "Berlusconi: The Film".

2021–22 South-West Indian Ocean cyclone season

The 2021–22 South-West Indian Ocean cyclone season was a period of intense tropical cyclone activity that occurred in the South-West Indian Ocean, which includes the area to the west of 90°E and to the south of the equator. The season officially began on July 1, 2021, and ended on June 30, 2022. This season was notable for the high number of intense tropical cyclones that formed, with several systems bringing significant impacts to the coastal regions of Madagascar, Mozambique, and Réunion.

# Seasonal summary

The 2021–22 South-West Indian Ocean cyclone season was a relatively active season, with a total of 12 named storms, 7 of which reached tropical cyclone intensity. The season saw a significant increase in activity compared to the previous season, with several systems forming in the early part of the season. The most notable systems of the season were Intense Tropical Cyclone Batsirai, which brought catastrophic damage to Madagascar, and Intense Tropical Cyclone Emnati, which affected the Mascarene Islands.

Severe Tropical Storm Ana was the first named storm of the season, forming on January 17, 2022, to the north of Madagascar. Levantine Arabic
================

Levantine Arabic, also known as Shami or Eastern Arabic, is a dialect of Arabic spoken in the Levant region, which includes countries such as Lebanon, Syria, Jordan, Palestine, and parts of Turkey and Iraq. It is one of the most widely spoken dialects of Arabic and has a rich history and cultural significance in the region.

Naming and classification
------------------------

Levantine Arabic is a member of the Arabic language family and is classified as a dialect of Modern Standard Arabic (MSA). However, it has distinct features and differences from MSA, which is the official language of many Arab countries. Levantine Arabic is often referred to as a "dialect" rather than a "language" because it is not considered a separate language from Arabic, but rather a regional variation.

Geographical distribution and varieties
--------------------------------------

### Dialects

Levantine Arabic has several dialects, each with its own distinct features and variations. Some of the main dialects include:

* Lebanese Arabic: spoken in Lebanon and parts of Syria
* Syrian Arabic: spoken in Syria and parts of Lebanon
* Jordanian Arabic: spoken in Jordan and parts of Palestine
* Palestinian Arabic: spoken in Palestine and parts of Jordan

### Ethnicity and religion

Levantine Arabic is spoken by people of various ethnic and religious backgrounds, including Arabs, Armenians, Kurds, and others. The majority of speakers are Sunni Muslims, but there are also significant numbers of Shia Muslims, Christians, and Druze.

### Speakers by country

* Lebanon: 4 million speakers
* Syria: 17 million speakers
* Jordan: 6 million speakers
* Palestine: 2 million speakers
* Turkey: 1 million speakers
* Iraq: 500,000 speakers

History
-------

### Pre-Islamic antiquity

The Levant region has a long history of human habitation, dating back to the Neolithic period. The region was home to various ancient civilizations, including the Phoenicians, Canaanites, and Aramaeans. These civilizations spoke various languages, including Phoenician, Canaanite, and Aramaic.

### Muslim conquest of the Levant

In the 7th century, the Levant region was conquered by the Arabs, who brought with them the Arabic language and Islam. The Arabic language gradually replaced the local languages, and the region became a major center of Arabic culture and learning.

### Medieval and early modern era

During the Middle Ages, the Levant region was a major center of trade and commerce, and the Arabic language played a significant role in this. The region was also home to various Islamic dynasties, including the Umayyads and the Abbasids.

### 20th and 21st centuries

In the 20th century, the Levant region underwent significant changes, including the establishment of modern nation-states and the displacement of Palestinians during the 1948 Arab-Israeli War. Today, the region is home to a diverse range of cultures and languages, and the Arabic language continues to play a significant role in the region.

Status and usage
----------------

### Diglossia and code-switching

Levantine Arabic is a diglossic language, meaning that it has two forms: a formal, standardized form used in writing and formal situations, and a colloquial, informal form used in everyday conversation. Many speakers also engage in code-switching, switching between Levantine Arabic and other languages, such as Modern Standard Arabic or foreign languages.

### Education

Levantine Arabic is not typically taught in schools, and Modern Standard Arabic is the primary language of education. However, some schools in Lebanon and Syria teach Levantine Arabic as a secondary language.

### Films and music

Levantine Arabic is widely used in films and music in the region. Many popular films and TV shows are produced in the Levant region, and the language is also used in music and song.

### Written media

Levantine Arabic is not typically written, and Modern Standard Arabic is the primary language of written communication. However, some newspapers and magazines in the region use Levantine Arabic in their publications.

Phonology
----------

Levantine Arabic has a distinct phonology, with a range of sounds that are not found in Modern Standard Arabic. Some of the key features of Levantine Arabic phonology include:

* The use of the "q" sound, which is pronounced as a deep "k" sound
* The use of the "j" sound, which is pronounced as a "y" sound
* The use of the "kh" sound, which is pronounced as a deep "kh" sound

Orthography and writing systems
-----------------------------

Levantine Arabic is not typically written, and Modern Standard Arabic is the primary language of written communication. However, some systems have been developed to write Levantine Arabic, including the use of Latin letters and Arabic script.

Grammar
-------

### Nouns and noun phrases

Levantine Arabic has a complex system of nouns and noun phrases, with a range of suffixes and prefixes used to indicate grammatical function. Some of the key features of Levantine Arabic nouns and noun phrases include:

* The use of suffixes to indicate possession and grammatical function
* The use of prefixes to indicate definiteness and grammatical function

### Pronouns

Levantine Arabic has a range of pronouns, including personal pronouns, demonstrative pronouns, and interrogative pronouns. Some of the key features of Levantine Arabic pronouns include:

* The use of suffixes to indicate grammatical function
* The use of prefixes to indicate definiteness and grammatical function

### Verbs and verb phrases

#### Root and verb forms

Levantine Arabic verbs are based on a system of roots and patterns, with a range of suffixes and prefixes used to indicate grammatical function. Some of the key features of Levantine Arabic roots and verb forms include:

article:
Big Brother 24 (American season)

Big Brother 24 is the twenty-fourth season of the American reality television series Big Brother. The season premiered on July 6, 2022, and concluded on September 25, 2022. This season featured a total of 16 new HouseGuests competing for a grand prize of $750,000.

# Format

The format of Big Brother 24 remained largely unchanged from previous seasons. A group of HouseGuests, also known as contestants, lived together in a custom-built house with cameras and microphones recording their every move, 24 hours a day, 7 days a week. Each week, the HouseGuests competed in competitions to win power and safety in the house, with the ultimate goal of being the last HouseGuest standing and winning the grand prize.

# HouseGuests

The 16 HouseGuests competing in Big Brother 24 were:

* Alyssa Snider
* Brittany Hoopes
* Daniel Durston
* Indy Santos
* Jasmine Davis
* Joseph Abdin
* Kyle Capener
* Marie "Taylor" Hale
* Matthew "Turner" Turner
* Michael "Monte" Taylor
* Nicole Layog
* Paloma Aguilar
* Taylor Hale
* Terrance Higgins
* Tyler Crispen

## Future appearances

Several HouseGuests from Big Brother 24 have made appearances on other reality television shows and events. Taylor Hale, the winner of Big Brother 24, appeared on The Bold and the Beautiful, a popular soap opera, and also competed on The Challenge, a reality competition series.

# Episodes

Big Brother 24 consisted of 36 episodes, which aired over the course of 12 weeks. Each episode featured a unique competition, twist, or dramatic event that affected the HouseGuests and their gameplay.

# Twists

Big Brother 24 featured several twists that impacted the gameplay and dynamics of the house.

## Backstage Boss

The "Backstage Boss" twist allowed a HouseGuest to gain control of the house and make nominations without being seen by the other HouseGuests. This twist was introduced in week 2 and was used by Kyle Capener, who made nominations that ultimately led to the eviction of Paloma Aguilar.

## Festie Besties

The "Festie Besties" twist paired HouseGuests together as "besties" and gave them a shared goal to work towards. This twist was introduced in week 3 and led to the formation of several strong alliances in the house.

## Split House Double Eviction

The "Split House Double Eviction" twist divided the house into two separate groups, with each group competing in their own competitions and having their own nominations and evictions. This twist was introduced in week 7 and led to the eviction of two HouseGuests, Daniel Durston and Nicole Layog.

# Voting history

The voting history of Big Brother 24 is as follows:

* Week 1: Alyssa Snider nominated, saved by Power of Veto
* Week 2: Paloma Aguilar nominated, evicted
* Week 3: Taylor Hale nominated, saved by Power of Veto
* Week 4: Brittany Hoopes nominated, evicted
* Week 5: Indy Santos nominated, saved by Power of Veto
* Week 6: Jasmine Davis nominated, evicted
* Week 7: Daniel Durston and Nicole Layog nominated, both evicted
* Week 8: Terrance Higgins nominated, saved by Power of Veto
* Week 9: Kyle Capener nominated, evicted
* Week 10: Michael "Monte" Taylor nominated, saved by Power of Veto
* Week 11: Alyssa Snider nominated, evicted
* Week 12: Brittany Hoopes, Indy Santos, and Michael "Monte" Taylor nominated, all evicted

# Production

Big Brother 24 was produced by Fly on the Wall Entertainment and Endemol Shine North America.

## Development

The development of Big Brother 24 began in early 2022, with casting calls and applications accepted from potential HouseGuests.

## Prize

The grand prize for Big Brother 24 was $750,000, awarded to the last HouseGuest standing.

## Production design

The Big Brother house was designed and built by a team of architects and designers, with a focus on creating a unique and functional living space for the HouseGuests.

# Reception

Big Brother 24 received mixed reviews from critics and viewers.

## Critical responses

### Mistreatment of Taylor Hale

Taylor Hale, the winner of Big Brother 24, was subject to mistreatment and bullying by some of her fellow HouseGuests. This behavior was widely criticized by viewers and critics, who felt that it was unacceptable and not adequately addressed by the show's producers.

### Kyle Capener's racial optics

Kyle Capener, a HouseGuest on Big Brother 24, was accused of using racial optics to further his own gameplay. This behavior was widely criticized by viewers and critics, who felt that it was unacceptable and not adequately addressed by the show's producers.

## Viewing figures

Big Brother 24 averaged a total of 4.3 million viewers per episode, with a peak of 5.5 million viewers for the season finale.

# References

Football at the 2022 Asian Games – Women's tournament

The women's football tournament at the 2022 Asian Games was the 7th edition of the women's football event at the Asian Games, which was held from September 21 to October 6, 2022, in Hangzhou, China. A total of 12 teams participated in the tournament, which was played in a round-robin format followed by a knockout stage.

# Competition schedule

The competition schedule for the women's football tournament at the 2022 Asian Games was as follows:

* Group stage: September 21-26, 2022
* Quarter-finals: September 28, 2022
* Semi-finals: October 2, 2022
* Bronze medal match: October 4, 2022
* Gold medal match: October 6, 2022

# Seed

The teams were seeded based on their performance at the 2018 Asian Games and other international tournaments. The top three teams in the seeding were China, Japan, and South Korea.

# Squads

Each team was allowed to have a maximum of 18 players in their squad, with three goalkeepers and 15 outfield players. The squads were announced before the start of the tournament.

# Venues

The women's football tournament was played at three venues in Hangzhou, China:

* Hangzhou Huanglong Stadium (capacity: 14,000)
* Hangzhou Dianshanhu Stadium (capacity: 10,000)
* Wenzhou Olympic Stadium (capacity: 18,000)

# Group stage

article:
Cyclone Batsirai

Cyclone Batsirai was a powerful tropical cyclone that brought widespread damage and disruption to the islands of Mauritius, Réunion, and Madagascar in the southwestern Indian Ocean in February 2022. The system was the second named storm of the 2021-22 South-West Indian Ocean cyclone season.

# Meteorological history

Cyclone Batsirai originated from a tropical disturbance that was first monitored by the Météo-France on January 24, 2022. The system was located in the central part of the South-West Indian Ocean, approximately 1,000 km (620 mi) north of Rodrigues Island. Over the next few days, the disturbance gradually developed, with convection increasing and banding features becoming more defined. On January 27, the system intensified into a tropical depression, and the Météo-France assigned it the name Batsirai.

As Batsirai continued to strengthen, it began to take on a more northwesterly track, driven by a subtropical ridge to the south. On January 29, the cyclone reached severe tropical storm intensity, with maximum sustained winds of 100 km/h (62 mph). Further intensification occurred over the next 24 hours, and Batsirai reached tropical cyclone intensity on January 30, with winds of 120 km/h (75 mph).

Batsirai continued to intensify over the next few days, reaching peak intensity on February 2, with maximum sustained winds of 195 km/h (121 mph) and a minimum central pressure of 940 hPa (27.36 inHg). At this time, the cyclone was located approximately 500 km (310 mi) east of Mauritius. However, shortly after reaching peak intensity, Batsirai began to weaken due to increasing vertical wind shear and decreasing sea surface temperatures.

# Preparations

## Mauritius

As Cyclone Batsirai approached Mauritius, the island's authorities took various measures to prepare for the storm. On January 31, the Mauritius Meteorological Service issued a Class 3 cyclone warning, indicating that the storm was expected to bring strong winds and heavy rainfall. The warning was later upgraded to Class 4 on February 1, as the cyclone's intensity increased.

The government of Mauritius declared a state of emergency, and schools, universities, and government offices were closed. The Mauritius Ports Authority closed the Port Louis harbor, and all fishing activities were suspended. The Mauritius Electricity and Water Authority also took measures to prepare for potential power outages.

## Madagascar

In Madagascar, the national meteorological agency, the Météorologie Nationale, issued a cyclone warning on January 31, as Batsirai was expected to make landfall on the eastern coast of the island. The agency warned of strong winds, heavy rainfall, and storm surges, and advised people to take necessary precautions.

The government of Madagascar also took measures to prepare for the storm, including evacuating people from low-lying areas and distributing emergency supplies. The National Office for Disaster Risk Management (BNGRC) was activated, and emergency response teams were deployed to affected areas.

# Impact

## Mauritius

Cyclone Batsirai made landfall on Mauritius on February 2, bringing strong winds and heavy rainfall. The cyclone's eye passed directly over the island, causing widespread damage and disruption. The strongest winds were recorded at the Mauritius Meteorological Service's station at Le Morne, where gusts reached 234 km/h (145 mph).

The cyclone caused significant damage to buildings, roads, and infrastructure. Many trees were uprooted, and power lines were broken, leaving thousands of households without electricity. The Mauritius Ports Authority reported that several ships had broken their moorings and were drifting in the harbor.

## Réunion

Although Cyclone Batsirai did not make landfall on Réunion, the island was still affected by strong winds and heavy rainfall. The cyclone's outer rain bands brought rain and thunderstorms to the island, causing flash flooding and landslides.

## Madagascar

Cyclone Batsirai made landfall on Madagascar on February 5, bringing strong winds and heavy rainfall. The cyclone's eye passed over the eastern coast of the island, causing widespread damage and disruption. The strongest winds were recorded at the Météorologie Nationale's station at Vatomandry, where gusts reached 184 km/h (114 mph).

The cyclone caused significant damage to buildings, roads, and infrastructure. Many trees were uprooted, and power lines were broken, leaving thousands of households without electricity. The National Office for Disaster Risk Management reported that several people had been killed, and many more were injured.

# Aftermath

## Mauritius

In the aftermath of Cyclone Batsirai, the government of Mauritius declared a state of emergency and deployed emergency response teams to affected areas. The Mauritius Electricity and Water Authority worked to restore power and water supplies, while the Mauritius Ports Authority worked to clear the harbor and restore shipping operations.

## Madagascar

In Madagascar, the government declared a state of emergency and deployed emergency response teams to affected areas. The National Office for Disaster Risk Management worked to assess the damage and provide assistance to affected communities.

### International response

The international community responded to the disaster by providing humanitarian assistance to affected countries. The United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA) deployed a team to Madagascar to assess the damage and provide assistance. The World Food Programme (WFP) provided emergency food assistance to affected communities, while the United Nations Children's Fund (UNICEF) provided emergency supplies and assistance to affected children.

* Cyclone Kenneth

# Notes

This article is a general overview of Cyclone Batsirai and its impact on the southwestern Indian Ocean. For more detailed information, please refer to the references listed below.

article:
QAnon

QAnon is a conspiracy theory that originated on the internet forum 4chan in 2017. The theory posits that a secret cabal of powerful individuals, known as "the elite," are working to undermine the United States government and institutions. QAnon adherents believe that a figure known as "Q" is a high-ranking government official who is working to expose this cabal and bring about justice.

Background

### Pizzagate

QAnon draws heavily from the Pizzagate conspiracy theory, which emerged in 2016. Pizzagate claimed that high-ranking officials in the Democratic Party were involved in a child sex trafficking ring operating out of a pizza parlor in Washington, D.C. Although the theory was thoroughly debunked, it laid the groundwork for the QAnon movement.

### Influence of 4chan culture

QAnon emerged from the culture of 4chan, an imageboard website known for its anonymous posting and lack of moderation. 4chan's /pol/ board, where QAnon originated, is a hub for far-right and conspiracy-oriented content. The board's culture of anonymous posting and lack of accountability allowed QAnon to spread quickly and take on a life of its own.

### Previous "anons"

QAnon is not the first conspiracy theory to emerge from 4chan. Previous "anons" have included theories about the death of Supreme Court Justice Antonin Scalia and the "true" identity of the gunman in the Sandy Hook Elementary School shooting.

Origin and spread

### Mainstream attention

QAnon gained mainstream attention in 2018, when adherents began appearing at Trump rallies and other public events. The movement's use of distinctive symbolism, such as the "Q" logo and "Where We Go One We Go All" (WWG1WGA) slogan, helped to identify its followers.

### International following

QAnon has attracted a significant international following, with adherents in countries such as the United Kingdom, Canada, and Australia. The movement's online nature has allowed it to spread quickly across borders.

### Pastel QAnon

In 2020, a variant of QAnon known as "Pastel QAnon" emerged. Pastel QAnon is characterized by its use of pastel-colored imagery and a focus on "self-care" and "wellness." The variant is seen as a attempt to rebrand QAnon and make it more appealing to a wider audience.

Claims

### Q's posts

QAnon is centered around the figure of "Q," who posts cryptic messages on the internet forum 8chan (previously 4chan). Q's posts, known as "Q drops," are often vague and open to interpretation. However, they are seen by adherents as containing hidden meaning and codes that, when decoded, reveal the truth about the cabal.

### The cabal and "the Storm"

QAnon adherents believe that the cabal is a powerful and secretive group of individuals who are working to undermine the United States government and institutions. The cabal is said to be responsible for a wide range of crimes, including child sex trafficking and murder. QAnon adherents believe that a figure known as "Q" is working to expose the cabal and bring about justice, a event known as "the Storm."

### Child sex trafficking and satanic sacrifice

QAnon adherents believe that the cabal is involved in child sex trafficking and satanic sacrifice. This belief is based on a misinterpretation of a 2017 report by the National Human Trafficking Hotline, which found that the majority of reported human trafficking cases involved sex trafficking of minors.

### Other QAnon beliefs

QAnon adherents also believe in a wide range of other conspiracy theories, including the idea that the moon landing was faked and that 9/11 was an inside job.

Analysis

### Identity of Q

The true identity of Q is unknown. However, many theories have been proposed, including the idea that Q is a high-ranking government official or a group of individuals working together.

#### Multiple people

Some researchers have suggested that Q is not a single individual, but rather a group of people working together to create the QAnon narrative.

#### Paul Furber and the Watkins family

In 2020, a researcher named Fredrick Brennan identified a man named Paul Furber as a likely candidate for Q. Furber is a South African-born software developer who has been linked to the Watkins family, who own the 8chan forum where Q posts.

### Slogans and vocabulary

QAnon adherents use a distinctive set of slogans and vocabulary, including "Where We Go One We Go All" (WWG1WGA) and "Trust the Plan." This language is seen as a way of identifying fellow adherents and signaling support for the QAnon narrative.

### Derivative elements

QAnon has incorporated elements from a wide range of conspiracy theories and ideologies, including Christianity and antisemitism.

#### Christian themes

QAnon has incorporated a number of Christian themes, including the idea of a coming apocalypse and the struggle between good and evil.

#### Antisemitism

QAnon has also been linked to antisemitism, with some adherents promoting conspiracy theories about Jewish people and the Rothschild family.

### Appeal

QAnon's appeal is complex and multifaceted. However, some researchers have suggested that the movement's use of symbolism and mythology has helped to attract followers.

#### Disillusionment

QAnon has also been linked to disillusionment with mainstream politics and institutions. Adherents often see the movement as a way of challenging the existing power structure and bringing about change.

### Demographics

QAnon's demographic makeup is not well understood. However, some researchers have suggested that the movement has attracted a disproportionate number of white, middle-aged men.

Incidents

### Attempts to overturn the 2020 U.S. election

In 2020, QAnon adherents were involved in attempts to overturn the results of the U.S. presidential election. This included a number of violent incidents, including the storming of the U.S. Capitol.

### German coup attempt

In 2022, a group of QAnon adherents in Germany were arrested for allegedly plotting a coup. The group, which included a number of former military personnel, had planned to storm the German parliament and install a new government.

Reactions

### Media, advocacy groups, and public figures

QAnon has been widely criticized by media outlets, advocacy groups, and public figures. This has included accusations that the movement is promoting conspiracy theories and inciting violence.

### Official responses

#### FBI domestic terrorism assessment

In 2019, the FBI released a domestic terrorism assessment that identified QAnon as a potential threat. The assessment noted that QAnon's ideology was "very likely" to inspire violent acts.

#### Congressional resolution

In 2020, the U.S. House of Representatives passed a resolution condemning QAnon and urging law enforcement agencies to take action against the movement.

### Republican politicians and organizations

Some Republican politicians and organizations have been linked to QAnon. This has included accusations that these individuals and groups are promoting conspiracy theories and inciting violence.

### Connected individuals

#### Donald Trump

Donald Trump has been linked to QAnon, with some researchers suggesting that he has promoted the movement's ideology.

#### Mike Pence

Mike Pence has also been linked to QAnon, with some researchers suggesting that he has promoted the movement's ideology.

#### Michael Flynn

Michael Flynn, a former U.S. National Security Adviser, has been linked to QAnon. Flynn has promoted the movement's ideology and has appeared at QAnon events.

#### Lin Wood

Lin Wood, a lawyer and QAnon adherent, has been involved in a number of high-profile cases, including the defense of Kyle Rittenhouse.

#### Sidney Powell

Sidney Powell, a lawyer and QAnon adherent, has been involved in a number of high-profile cases, including the defense of Michael Flynn.

#### Kelly Townsend

Kelly Townsend, an Arizona state senator, has been linked to QAnon. Townsend has promoted the movement's ideology and has appeared at QAnon events.

#### Liz Harris

Liz Harris, an Arizona state representative, has been linked to QAnon. Harris has promoted the movement's ideology and has appeared at QAnon events.

Online

### QDrops app

The QDrops app is a mobile app that allows users to access Q's posts and other QAnon-related content.

### Anti-QAnon subreddits

A number of subreddits have been created to counter QAnon, including r/qanoncasualties and r/AgainstQAnon.

### Removal of content

In 2020, a number of social media platforms, including Twitter and Facebook, removed QAnon-related content from their sites.

### Migration to alt-tech

In response to the removal of content from mainstream social media platforms, QAnon adherents have migrated to alternative platforms, such as Gab and Parler.

### Return to Twitter/X

In 2022, QAnon adherents began to return to Twitter, which had previously banned the movement's content.

article:
2022 American League Division Series

The 2022 American League Division Series (ALDS) were a pair of best-of-five playoff series in Major League Baseball (MLB) that determined the participants in the 2022 American League Championship Series (ALCS). The ALDS began on October 7 and ended on October 16.

Background

The ALDS were the first postseason round in the 2022 MLB season, contested between the winners of the three American League (AL) divisions and a Wild Card team. The division winners, seeded 1 through 3 based on their regular season records, were the Houston Astros, the New York Yankees, and the Cleveland Guardians. The Seattle Mariners, who won the AL Wild Card, were the fourth team to qualify for the ALDS.

Matchups

### Houston Astros vs. Seattle Mariners

The Houston Astros, winners of the AL West division, faced the Seattle Mariners, the AL Wild Card winner, in the ALDS. The Astros entered the series as the top seed in the AL, having won 106 games in the regular season. The Mariners, meanwhile, were appearing in their first postseason since 2001.

### New York Yankees vs. Cleveland Guardians

The New York Yankees, winners of the AL East division, faced the Cleveland Guardians, winners of the AL Central division, in the ALDS. The Yankees were seeking to return to the ALCS for the first time since 2019, while the Guardians were looking to reach the ALCS for the first time since 2016.

Houston vs. Seattle

### Game 1

The Astros won Game 1, 8-7, in a back-and-forth contest that saw multiple lead changes. Yordan Alvarez hit a go-ahead home run in the 8th inning to put the Astros ahead for good.

### Game 2

The Astros took a 2-0 series lead with a 4-2 win in Game 2. Framber Valdez pitched 7 strong innings, allowing just 1 earned run, to earn the win.

### Game 3

The Astros completed the sweep with a 1-0 win in Game 3. Lance McCullers Jr. pitched 7 shutout innings, and the Astros' bullpen closed out the game to secure the series victory.

### Composite line score

Houston Astros 13, Seattle Mariners 9

New York vs. Cleveland

### Game 1

The Yankees won Game 1, 4-1, behind a strong start from Gerrit Cole. Cole pitched 6 1/3 innings, allowing just 1 earned run, to earn the win.

### Game 2

The Guardians evened the series with a 4-2 win in Game 2. Shane Bieber pitched 5 strong innings, and the Guardians' bullpen closed out the game to secure the win.

### Game 3

The Guardians took a 2-1 series lead with a 6-5 win in Game 3. The Guardians' offense came alive, scoring 6 runs on 11 hits, to take the lead in the series.

### Game 4

The Yankees evened the series with a 4-2 win in Game 4. Nestor Cortes pitched 5 strong innings, and the Yankees' bullpen closed out the game to secure the win.

### Game 5

The Yankees won the series with a 5-1 win in Game 5. Gerrit Cole pitched 7 strong innings, allowing just 1 earned run, to earn the win and send the Yankees to the ALCS.

### Composite line score

New York Yankees 19, Cleveland Guardians 14

article:
2023 Turkish Presidential Election

The 2023 Turkish presidential election is scheduled to take place on May 14, 2023, with a possible second round on May 28, 2023. The election will determine the President of Turkey, as well as the 28th President of the Republic of Turkey, who will serve a five-year term.

# Background

## 2018 Elections

The 2018 Turkish presidential election was held on June 24, 2018, and resulted in the re-election of Recep Tayyip Erdoğan as President of Turkey. The election was the first to be held under the new presidential system, which was established by a constitutional referendum in 2017. The new system abolished the office of the Prime Minister and granted the President sweeping executive powers.

# Date

## Discussion on Snap Elections

In the months leading up to the election, there was speculation about the possibility of snap elections being called. However, in January 2023, President Erdoğan announced that the election would be held on May 14, 2023, as scheduled.

## Discussion on Postponing Election Date

In February 2023, there were reports that the government was considering postponing the election date due to the aftermath of the 2023 Turkey-Syria earthquake. However, the idea was met with opposition from the opposition parties, and the election date remained unchanged.

## Election Calendar

The election calendar was announced by the Supreme Election Council (YSK) in March 2023. The calendar set out the key dates for the election, including the start of the official campaign period, the deadline for candidate nominations, and the dates for the first and second rounds of the election.

# Electoral System

The Turkish presidential election is held using a two-round system. In the first round, voters cast their ballots for one of the candidates. If no candidate receives more than 50% of the vote, a second round is held between the top two candidates. The candidate with the most votes in the second round is declared the winner.

# Candidates

## Candidates

A total of four candidates are running in the election:

* Recep Tayyip Erdoğan (Justice and Development Party)
* Kemal Kılıçdaroğlu (Republican People's Party)
* Sinan Oğan (Anatolia Alliance)
* Muharrem İnce (Homeland Party)

## Nominations

The deadline for candidate nominations was March 19, 2023. The nominations were submitted to the YSK, which verified the candidates' eligibility to run in the election.

## Endorsements

Several parties and alliances have endorsed candidates in the election:

* The Nation Alliance, which includes the Republican People's Party, the Good Party, and the Future Party, has endorsed Kemal Kılıçdaroğlu.
* The People's Alliance, which includes the Justice and Development Party and the Nationalist Movement Party, has endorsed Recep Tayyip Erdoğan.
* The Labour and Freedom Alliance, which includes the Workers' Party of Turkey and the Greens and the Left Future Party, has endorsed Kemal Kılıçdaroğlu.

# Second Round

## Negotiations by Oğan and Özdağ

In the days following the first round of the election, there were reports of negotiations between Sinan Oğan and Ümit Özdağ, the leaders of the Anatolia Alliance and the Victory Party, respectively. The negotiations were aimed at reaching an agreement on which candidate to support in the second round.

### Dissolution of ATA Alliance

On May 16, 2023, Sinan Oğan announced the dissolution of the Anatolia Alliance, which had been formed ahead of the election.

### Endorsement of Erdoğan by Oğan

On May 17, 2023, Sinan Oğan announced that he would endorse Recep Tayyip Erdoğan in the second round of the election.

### Özdağ's Support for Kılıçdaroğlu

On May 18, 2023, Ümit Özdağ announced that he would support Kemal Kılıçdaroğlu in the second round of the election.

## Erdoğan's Strategy

Recep Tayyip Erdoğan's strategy in the second round is focused on winning over voters who supported Sinan Oğan in the first round. Erdoğan has promised to implement policies that will benefit the country's rural areas, where Oğan's support was strongest.

## Kılıçdaroğlu's Strategy

Kemal Kılıçdaroğlu's strategy in the second round is focused on winning over voters who are disillusioned with Erdoğan's rule. Kılıçdaroğlu has promised to implement policies that will benefit the country's youth and working class.

## Potential Debate

There have been reports of a potential debate between Erdoğan and Kılıçdaroğlu ahead of the second round. However, the details of the debate have not been finalized.

# Controversies

## Erdoğan's Right to Seek Re-Election

There has been controversy over Recep Tayyip Erdoğan's right to seek re-election. Some have argued that the constitutional changes introduced in 2017, which allowed the President to serve two five-year terms, were designed to benefit Erdoğan specifically.

## Political Violence

There have been reports of political violence in the run-up to the election. Several opposition party members have been attacked, and there have been allegations of intimidation and harassment.

## Erdoğan's Photo on Ballot Paper

There has been controversy over the inclusion of Recep Tayyip Erdoğan's photo on the ballot paper. Some have argued that this gives Erdoğan an unfair advantage.

## Fake Videos

There have been reports of fake videos being circulated on social media, which appear to show opposition party members making inflammatory statements. The videos have been widely condemned as a form of disinformation.

## Block of Ekşi Sözlük

The Ekşi Sözlük website, a popular online forum, was blocked by the government ahead of the election. The block was widely condemned as a form of censorship.

## Reporting of the Results

There have been concerns about the reporting of the results, with some opposition parties expressing fears that the government may manipulate the outcome.

## Azerbaijani and Russian Interference Allegations

There have been allegations of interference in the election by Azerbaijan and Russia. Some have accused the two countries of providing financial and logistical support to Recep Tayyip Erdoğan's campaign.

# Opinion Polls

## First Round

Opinion polls ahead of the first round of the election showed Recep Tayyip Erdoğan and Kemal Kılıçdaroğlu running neck and neck. Sinan Oğan and Muharrem İnce trailed behind.

## Second Round

Opinion polls ahead of the second round of the election show Recep Tayyip Erdoğan and Kemal Kılıçdaroğlu running close. However, Erdoğan appears to have a slight lead.

# Results

The results of the election will be announced by the Supreme Election Council (YSK) on May 28, 2023.

## Analysis

The outcome of the election will have significant implications for Turkey's future. If Recep Tayyip Erdoğan wins, it is likely that he will continue to implement his policies, which have been widely criticized by opposition parties. If Kemal Kılıçdaroğlu wins, it is likely that he will implement policies that will benefit the country's youth and working class.

# Aftermath

## Domestic

The aftermath of the election is likely to be marked by protests and demonstrations, regardless of the outcome. Opposition parties have expressed fears that the government may manipulate the outcome, and there have been reports of intimidation and harassment.

## International

The international community will be watching the outcome of the election closely. The European Union and the United States have expressed concerns about the state of democracy in Turkey, and the outcome of the election is likely to have significant implications for the country's relationships with these countries.

article:
Clarence Thomas

Clarence Thomas is an Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States, serving since 1991. He is the second African American to serve on the Court, after Thurgood Marshall. Thomas has been a prominent figure in American politics and law, known for his conservative judicial philosophy and his role in many landmark Supreme Court cases.

Early life

Clarence Thomas was born on June 23, 1948, in Pin Point, Georgia, a small community near Savannah. He grew up in a poor Gullah Geechee community, where he spoke Gullah as his first language. Thomas's father abandoned the family when Thomas was two years old, and his mother remarried. However, Thomas's stepfather also abandoned the family, leaving Thomas's mother to care for him and his brother on her own.

Thomas was sent to live with his maternal grandparents in Savannah, where he attended St. Pius X High School. He later attended the College of the Holy Cross, where he graduated in 1971. Thomas then attended Yale Law School, where he earned his Juris Doctor (J.D.) degree in 1974.

College of the Holy Cross and Yale Law School

Thomas's time at the College of the Holy Cross was marked by academic excellence and leadership. He was a member of the school's debate team and was elected president of the student body. Thomas has credited his time at Holy Cross with instilling in him the values of discipline and hard work.

At Yale Law School, Thomas was one of only 12 African American students in his class. He was a member of the Yale Law Journal and was active in the school's Black Law Students Association. Thomas has said that his time at Yale Law School was marked by feelings of isolation and frustration, as he struggled to find his place in the predominantly white institution.

Early legal career

After graduating from Yale Law School, Thomas clerked for Judge John H. Pratt of the United States District Court for the District of Columbia. He then worked as an assistant attorney general for the state of Missouri, where he was responsible for arguing cases before the Missouri Supreme Court.

In 1977, Thomas became a legislative assistant to Senator John Danforth of Missouri. He worked on a number of high-profile legislative initiatives, including the Occupational Safety and Health Act and the Americans with Disabilities Act.

District of Columbia Court of Appeals

In 1990, Thomas was nominated by President George H.W. Bush to serve on the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit. He was confirmed by the Senate in 1991, just months before he was nominated to the Supreme Court.

Nomination to the Supreme Court

Thomas was nominated to the Supreme Court by President George H.W. Bush on July 1, 1991, to replace retiring Justice Thurgood Marshall. The nomination was seen as a surprise, as Thomas was relatively unknown at the time.

Anita Hill accusations

During Thomas's confirmation hearings, Anita Hill, a former colleague of Thomas's at the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC), came forward with allegations of sexual harassment. Hill testified that Thomas had made unwanted advances and comments during their time working together.

Second hearing

The Senate Judiciary Committee held a second hearing to investigate Hill's allegations. Thomas denied the allegations, calling them "a high-tech lynching." The hearing was widely covered in the media and sparked a national debate about sexual harassment and racism.

Senate votes

The Senate voted 52-48 to confirm Thomas to the Supreme Court on October 15, 1991. Thomas was sworn in as an Associate Justice on October 23, 1991.

Supreme Court of the United States

Thomas has been a member of the Supreme Court for over 30 years, during which time he has developed a reputation as a conservative jurist. He has been a key player in many landmark cases, including decisions on abortion, gun control, and affirmative action.

Government powers and legal structure

Thomas has been a strong advocate for limited government and individual rights. He has argued that the Constitution sets out clear limits on the power of the federal government and that the Court should be hesitant to expand those powers.

Court precedent

Thomas has been critical of the Court's use of precedent, arguing that it can be used to justify judicial activism. He has advocated for a more originalist approach to interpreting the Constitution, one that looks to the original meaning of the text rather than later interpretations.

Executive power

Thomas has been a strong supporter of executive power, arguing that the President has broad authority to act in the national interest. He has defended the President's power to appoint officials and to conduct foreign policy, even in the face of opposition from Congress.

Federalism and states' rights

Thomas has been a strong advocate for federalism and states' rights. He has argued that the Constitution sets out clear limits on the power of the federal government and that states should be free to experiment with different policies and approaches.

Individual rights

Thomas has been a strong supporter of individual rights, including the right to bear arms and the right to free speech. He has argued that these rights are essential to a free and functioning society.

First Amendment

Thomas has been a strong supporter of the First Amendment, which protects the right to free speech and the freedom of the press. He has argued that the First Amendment sets out clear limits on the power of the government to regulate speech and that the Court should be hesitant to expand those limits.

Second Amendment

Thomas has been a strong supporter of the Second Amendment, which protects the right to bear arms. He has argued that the Second Amendment sets out a clear right to individual self-defense and that the Court should be hesitant to limit that right.

Fourth Amendment

Thomas has been critical of the Court's interpretation of the Fourth Amendment, which protects against unreasonable searches and seizures. He has argued that the Court has been too willing to allow warrantless searches and seizures and that the Fourth Amendment sets out clear limits on the power of the government to conduct searches.

Sixth Amendment

Thomas has been a strong supporter of the Sixth Amendment, which protects the right to a fair trial. He has argued that the Sixth Amendment sets out clear limits on the power of the government to regulate trials and that the Court should be hesitant to expand those limits.

Eighth Amendment

Thomas has been critical of the Court's interpretation of the Eighth Amendment, which prohibits cruel and unusual punishment. He has argued that the Court has been too willing to allow the use of capital punishment and that the Eighth Amendment sets out clear limits on the power of the government to punish.

Fourteenth Amendment

Thomas has been a strong supporter of the Fourteenth Amendment, which protects the right to equal protection under the law. He has argued that the Fourteenth Amendment sets out clear limits on the power of the government to discriminate and that the Court should be hesitant to expand those limits.

Abortion and family planning

Thomas has been a strong opponent of abortion and has argued that the Constitution does not protect a right to abortion. He has voted to uphold restrictions on abortion and has argued that the Court should be hesitant to strike down laws that regulate abortion.

LGBTQ rights

Thomas has been a strong opponent of LGBTQ rights and has argued that the Constitution does not protect a right to same-sex marriage. He has voted to uphold restrictions on LGBTQ rights and has argued that the Court should be hesitant to strike down laws that regulate LGBTQ rights.

Oral arguments

Thomas has been known for his relatively quiet approach to oral arguments, often asking few questions and allowing other justices to take the lead. However, he has been a strong advocate for his own views and has not hesitated to speak out when he disagrees with other justices.

Personal life

Thomas has been married to his wife, Ginni, since 1987. The couple has one son, Jamal, who was born in 1973. Thomas has been a strong advocate for his family and has prioritized his family life throughout his career.

Family

Thomas has spoken publicly about the importance of his family and has credited his wife and son with supporting him throughout his career. He has also spoken about the challenges of balancing work and family life, particularly in the early years of his career.

Religion

Thomas is a Catholic and has spoken publicly about the importance of his faith. He has credited his faith with instilling in him the values of discipline and hard work.

Literary influences

Thomas has spoken publicly about the influence of literary figures such as Frederick Douglass and Booker T. Washington on his life and work. He has credited these figures with shaping his views on education and self-reliance.

Moira Smith allegations

In 2020, Moira Smith, a former employee of Thomas's, came forward with allegations of misconduct. Smith alleged that Thomas had made unwanted advances and comments during her time working for him. Thomas denied the allegations, calling them "unsubstantiated" and "untrue."

Nondisclosure of finances

Thomas has been criticized for not disclosing his finances, particularly in the early years of his career. He has argued that he was not required to disclose his finances and that the criticism is unfair.

Honors and recognition

Thomas has received a number of honors and awards throughout his career, including the National Bar Association's highest award for public service.

In popular culture

Thomas has been portrayed in a number of films and television shows, including the 2016 film "Confirmation" and the 2019 television series "The Oval."

Writings

2022 World Women's Curling Championship

The 2022 World Women's Curling Championship was held from March 19 to 27, 2022, at the CN Centre in Prince George, British Columbia, Canada. This was the 43rd edition of the championship, which was originally scheduled to take place in 2021 but was postponed due to the COVID-19 pandemic.

#Qualification

##Russian participation

In February 2022, the World Curling Federation (WCF) announced that Russia would not be allowed to participate in the championship due to the country's invasion of Ukraine. The Russian Curling Federation was suspended, and the team was withdrawn from the competition.

##COVID-19 issues

The COVID-19 pandemic had a significant impact on the championship, with several teams facing challenges related to travel and quarantine restrictions.

###Scotland

The Scottish team was forced to withdraw from the competition due to COVID-19 issues. The team's skip, Eve Muirhead, tested positive for the virus, and several other team members were deemed close contacts.

###Japan

The Japanese team also faced COVID-19 issues, with several team members testing positive for the virus. Despite this, the team was able to participate in the championship, albeit with some adjustments to their lineup.

#Teams

A total of 13 teams participated in the championship, representing their respective countries and curling associations. The teams were:

*  Canada (represented by the Kerri Einarson rink)

article:
Olivia Newton-John

Dame Olivia Newton-John AC DBE is a British-Australian singer, actress, and activist who has become one of the most successful and beloved artists of all time. With a career spanning over five decades, Newton-John has achieved unparalleled success in the music industry, with over 100 million records sold worldwide, making her one of the best-selling artists of all time.

#Early life and family

Olivia Newton-John was born on September 26, 1948, in Cambridge, England, to Brinley Newton-John and Irene Born. Her father was a Welsh-born professor of German and her mother was born in the UK but raised in Australia. Newton-John has an older brother, Hugh, and an older sister, Rona. When Newton-John was six years old, her family emigrated to Melbourne, Australia, where she grew up.

#Career

##Career beginnings

Newton-John's interest in music began at an early age, and she began singing in her church choir and at local talent shows. At 14, she formed a girl group called The Sol Four, which performed at local coffee shops and shopping centers. Newton-John's big break came when she won a talent contest on a local Australian television show, which led to her being discovered by a local record producer.

##1971–1974: Early success

Newton-John released her debut album, "If Not for You," in 1971, which was moderately successful in Australia. However, it was her 1973 single "Let Me Be There" that brought her international success, reaching the top 10 in the US and earning her a Grammy Award for Best Female Pop Vocal Performance.

##1975–1977: Have You Never Been Mellow, Clearly Love, and continued success

Newton-John's 1975 album "Have You Never Been Mellow" was a huge success, reaching number one in the US and spawning the hit singles "Have You Never Been Mellow" and "Please Mr. Please." Her 1976 album "Clearly Love" was also successful, with the hit single "Something Better to Do." Newton-John's success continued throughout the late 1970s, with hits like "Sam" and "You're the One That I Want."

##1978–1979: Grease and Totally Hot

Newton-John's 1978 role as Sandy Olsson in the musical film "Grease" cemented her status as a global superstar. The film's soundtrack, which featured Newton-John's duets with John Travolta, including the iconic hit "You're the One That I Want," became one of the best-selling soundtracks of all time.

Newton-John's 1978 album "Totally Hot" was a commercial success, with the hit singles "A Little More Love" and "Deeper Than a River."

###Lawsuit against MCA Records

In 1979, Newton-John filed a lawsuit against her record label, MCA Records, alleging that the company had underpaid her royalties and breached her contract. The lawsuit was settled out of court for an undisclosed amount.

##1980–1988: Physical, Soul Kiss, and The Rumour

Newton-John's 1980 album "Xanadu" was the soundtrack to the film of the same name, in which she starred alongside Gene Kelly. The album was a commercial success, with the hit singles "Magic" and "Xanadu."

Newton-John's 1981 album "Physical" was a huge success, with the hit singles "Physical" and "Make a Move On Me." The album's success was fueled by Newton-John's iconic music videos and her increasingly provocative stage shows.

Newton-John's 1984 album "Soul Kiss" was a moderate success, with the hit single "Soul Kiss." Her 1986 album "The Rumour" was also moderately successful, with the hit single "The Rumour."

##1989–1998: Motherhood, cancer, and advocacy

In 1989, Newton-John married actor Matt Lattanzi and gave birth to their daughter, Chloe Rose Lattanzi. Newton-John's music career slowed down during this period, as she focused on raising her daughter and advocating for various charitable causes.

In 1992, Newton-John was diagnosed with breast cancer, which she successfully treated. Newton-John's experience with cancer led her to become a prominent advocate for breast cancer research and awareness.

##1998–2012: Later releases

Newton-John released several albums in the late 1990s and early 2000s, including "Back to Basics" (1992), "Gaia" (1994), and "One Woman's Live Journey" (2000). Her 2006 album "Stronger Than Before" was a moderate success, with the hit single "Phenomenal Woman."

##2012–2022: Vegas residency and final releases

In 2012, Newton-John began a residency at the Flamingo Las Vegas, which ran for several years. Newton-John also released several albums during this period, including "This Christmas" (2012), "Hotel Sessions" (2014), and "Friends for Christmas" (2016).

#In the media

Newton-John has been the subject of numerous media profiles and documentaries, including a 2008 A&E Biography special and a 2018 ABC Australia documentary.

#Musical legacy

Newton-John's music has had a lasting impact on the industry, with her iconic hits like "Physical" and "You're the One That I Want" remaining popular to this day. Newton-John has been named one of the greatest singers of all time by various publications, including Rolling Stone and Billboard.

#Personal life

##Relationships

Newton-John has been married twice, first to actor Matt Lattanzi from 1984 to 1995 and then to John Easterling from 2008 to present.

##Residences and citizenship

Newton-John has lived in various locations throughout her life, including Australia, the US, and the UK. She holds dual citizenship of Australia and the UK.

#Illness and death

On August 8, 2022, Olivia Newton-John passed away at the age of 73, after a long battle with breast cancer.

#Awards and honours

Newton-John has won numerous awards and honors throughout her career, including four Grammy Awards, a Primetime Emmy Award, and a star on the Hollywood Walk of Fame.

article:
Max Wenner

Max Wenner was a renowned American businessman and philanthropist who made significant contributions to various fields, including finance, education, and healthcare. Throughout his life, Wenner was known for his exceptional leadership skills, innovative ideas, and generosity. article:
Harry Belafonte

Harold George Bellanfanti Jr., known professionally as Harry Belafonte, is a Jamaican-American singer, songwriter, actor, and social activist. One of the most successful Caribbean artists of all time, Belafonte has been a major figure in popular music for over six decades. He is best known for his signature calypso style, as well as his advocacy for civil rights and humanitarian causes.

#Early life

Harry Belafonte was born on March 1, 1927, in Harlem, New York, to Melvine (née Love) and Harold George Bellanfanti, a Jamaican chef. His mother was of African and Scottish descent, and his father was of African and Spanish descent. Belafonte's parents divorced when he was young, and he was raised by his mother in the Lyncourt Apartments in Harlem. He developed a love for music at an early age, listening to jazz and blues records and singing in church choirs.

#Musical career

##Early years (1949–1955)

Belafonte began his music career in the late 1940s, performing in jazz clubs and theaters in New York City. He won a Tony Award for his portrayal of Joe in the 1949 Broadway production of "John Murray Anderson's Almanac." In the early 1950s, he began recording music, releasing several singles and EPs on the Jubilee and RCA Victor labels.

##Rise to fame (1956–1958)

Belafonte's breakthrough came in 1956 with the release of his album "Calypso," which included the hit singles "Jamaica Farewell" and "Day-O (The Banana Boat Song)." The album became a huge commercial success, selling over a million copies and establishing Belafonte as a major star.

##Middle career (1959–1970)

In the late 1950s and 1960s, Belafonte continued to release hit albums and singles, including "Belafonte Sings of the Caribbean" and "Jump in the Line." He also began to explore other musical styles, including folk and pop. In 1961, he released the album "Belafonte Folk Singers," which featured traditional folk songs from around the world.

##Later recordings and subsequent activities (1971–2017)

In the 1970s and 1980s, Belafonte continued to release music, but at a slower pace. He also became increasingly involved in humanitarian and activist work. In the 1990s and 2000s, he released several albums, including "Turn the World Around" and "When Colors Come Together." In 2011, he released the album "My Song," which featured re-recordings of some of his classic hits.

#Film career

##Early film career (1953–1956)

Belafonte began his film career in the early 1950s, appearing in small roles in films such as "Bright Road" and "Carmen Jones." His breakthrough came in 1956 with the film "Island in the Sun," which starred Dorothy Dandridge and James Mason.

##Rise as an actor (1957–1959)

In the late 1950s, Belafonte established himself as a leading man in films such as "Edge of the City" and "The St. Louis Blues." He also began to produce films, including the 1959 film "Odds Against Tomorrow."

##Later film and theatre involvement (1960–2018)

In the 1960s and 1970s, Belafonte continued to appear in films and on stage. He starred in the 1960 film "The Angel Levine," and appeared on Broadway in productions such as "I Had a Ball" and "The Roast." In the 1980s and 1990s, he appeared in films such as "Buck and the Preacher" and "Kansas City." In 2018, he appeared in the film "BlacKkKlansman," directed by Spike Lee.

#Political activism

##Involvement in the civil rights movement

Belafonte was a key figure in the civil rights movement of the 1950s and 1960s. He was a close friend and supporter of Martin Luther King Jr., and participated in several major civil rights events, including the 1963 March on Washington.

##Involvement in the Kennedy campaign

In 1960, Belafonte supported the presidential campaign of John F. Kennedy. He performed at several campaign rallies and events, and was a key figure in Kennedy's efforts to reach African American voters.

##The Baldwin-Kennedy Meeting

In 1963, Belafonte helped to arrange a meeting between author James Baldwin and Attorney General Robert F. Kennedy. The meeting was an attempt to discuss the growing tensions between the civil rights movement and the Kennedy administration.

##Obama administration

In 2008, Belafonte supported the presidential campaign of Barack Obama. He performed at several campaign rallies and events, and was a key figure in Obama's efforts to reach African American voters.

##Support for Bernie Sanders

In 2016, Belafonte supported the presidential campaign of Bernie Sanders. He performed at several campaign rallies and events, and was a key figure in Sanders' efforts to reach African American voters.

##The Sanders Institute

In 2017, Belafonte was named a fellow of the Sanders Institute, a think tank founded by Bernie Sanders and his wife Jane.

#Humanitarian activism

##HIV/AIDS crisis

In the 1980s and 1990s, Belafonte was a key figure in the fight against HIV/AIDS. He worked closely with organizations such as the Gay Men's Health Crisis and the AIDS Coalition to Unleash Power.

##Prostate Cancer awareness

In the 1990s and 2000s, Belafonte worked to raise awareness about prostate cancer. He appeared in several public service announcements and worked with organizations such as the Prostate Cancer Foundation.

##Work with UNICEF

In the 1990s and 2000s, Belafonte worked closely with UNICEF on several humanitarian projects. He traveled to several countries, including Somalia and Rwanda, to raise awareness about the needs of children in crisis.

##Various Activist work

Belafonte has been involved in a wide range of other activist causes, including environmentalism, anti-war efforts, and human rights work. He has worked closely with organizations such as the Sierra Club, the American Civil Liberties Union, and Amnesty International.

##New York City Pride Parade

In 2019, Belafonte was the grand marshal of the New York City Pride Parade.

#Belafonte and foreign policy

##Opposition to the George W. Bush administration

In the 2000s, Belafonte was a vocal critic of the foreign policy of the George W. Bush administration. He opposed the invasion of Iraq and worked closely with organizations such as the Iraq Veterans Against the War.

#Business career

Belafonte has been involved in several business ventures over the years, including a production company and a record label. He has also worked as a consultant and advisor to several major corporations.

#Personal life, health and death

Belafonte has been married three times, to Marguerite Byrd, Julie Robinson, and Pamela Frank. He has four children and several grandchildren. In 2019, he announced that he was suffering from dementia and would be retiring from public life.
